courseTitle: Single Replacement Reaction Stoichiometry and Percent Yield

pageData.text: In this experiment, aluminum metal is reacted with copper sulfate to produce copper metal. The first step will determine the <button class='glossary-text'>limiting reactant</button> of the reaction and the <button class='glossary-text'>theoretical yield</button> produced from the reactant starting quantities. The theoretical yield is then compared with the <button class='glossary-text'>actual yield</button> obtained and the <button class='glossary-text'>percent yield</button> calculated.

text: Balance chemical equations.

Use <button class='glossary-text'>stoichiometry</button> as a tool to determine <button class='glossary-text'>limiting reactants</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>theoretical yields</button>.
Quantitatively analyze the chemical reaction product(s).
Calculate <button class='glossary-text'>percent yield</button>.

pageData.text: The Statue of Liberty underwent a major restoration in the 1980s to help circumvent a serious problem: we had turned the Statue of Liberty into a battery. This was done by unknowingly subjecting it to a single replacement reaction over the course of half a century. Within the structure is an iron frame which went through years of maintenance, including new coats of varnish and paint. Oftentimes such coatings were applied without properly drying the surfaces, trapping salt water from the harbor between the iron frame and the copper statue. The iron, salt and copper together underwent a single replacement reaction like that found in an iron battery. Although the Statue of Liberty only produced about a quarter of a volt of electricity, it did so for over 50 years.

pageData.altText: The Statue of Liberty.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Stoichiometry</button> enables chemists to calculate quantitative relationships between reactants and products in a chemical reaction. A balanced chemical equation indicates the reactant proportions required to generate products. Balanced chemical equations allow you to derive mole ratios of the reactants and products from the coefficients in the reaction. Stoichiometry calculations are used to convert these mole ratios into mass or volume and vice versa.

Stoichiometry calculations are used to calculate the amounts of substances that react and how much they produce in a chemical reaction. The word “stoichiometry” comes from the Greek stoikheion “element” and metriā “measure.” Using a balanced chemical equation and the molar mass or concentration of the reactants, the amount of product formed can be calculated. Stoichiometry is also used to determine , , or how much reactant is needed to prepare a specific amount of product.

If the reactants are not present in the correct molar ratio based on the balanced chemical equation, then one of the reactants will be consumed first. The amount of product generated will be limited by the fully consumed reactant. This is called the <button class='glossary-text'>limiting reactant</button> or limiting reagent. The reactant that is left over is called the <button class='glossary-text'>excess reactant</button> or reagent.

Once the limiting reactant has been determined, the amount of product generated can be calculated. This is called the theoretical yield. After the experiment has been completed, the <button class='glossary-text'>actual yield</button> can be determined and the percent yield calculated by dividing the actual yield by the theoretical yield and multiplying by one hundred.

The first step in stoichiometry is to balance the equation and determine the mole ratios of all the reactants and products. The second step is to take the mass or volume data provided and convert them into moles. For mass, use the molar mass, also known as formula weight, to convert to moles. For solutions use the molarity and volume to calculate moles. If the reactant is a gas, remember that one mole of any gas at standard temperature and pressure (STP) equals 22.4 L. After the molar quantities of each reactant have been calculated, the theoretical yield of the products can be determined using the mole ratio from the balanced equation.

When performing stoichiometric calculations the units are very important. Always include the units and cancel them out during the calculations. This is a good double check to ensure that you are using the correct data, units, and equations.

pageData.subTitle: Solving Stoichiometric Calculations
pageData.text: To determine product yield from stoichiometric calculations, use the following six-step process.

pageData.title: Step 1:
pageData.text: Write a balanced chemical equation for the reaction.

pageData.title: Step 2:
pageData.text: Balance the electric charges in the chemical equations.

pageData.title: Step 3:
pageData.text: Calculate the number of moles of each reactant.

pageData.title: Step 4:
pageData.text: Determine if one of the reactants is a . Figure 1 shows an example of a limiting reagent.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: An analogy of a chemical reaction. 6 bread buns and 2 slices of cheese are on the left side of the equation as reactants. The cheese is labeled the limiting reactant. On the right side of the equation are 2 cheese sandwiches, each comprised of 2 buns and 1 slice of cheese. These sandwiches are labeled the theoretical yield. Also produced by the equation are 2 buns, which are labeled as excess reagent.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: An analogy of a chemical reaction. 6 bread buns and 2 slices of cheese are on the left side of the equation as reactants. The cheese is labeled the limiting reactant. On the right side of the equation are 2 cheese sandwiches, each comprised of 2 buns and 1 slice of cheese. These sandwiches are labeled the theoretical yield. Also produced by the equation are 2 buns, which are labeled as excess reagent.

pageData.title: Step 5:
pageData.text: Calculate the number of moles of product produced based on the number of moles of the limiting reactant and the balanced chemical equation.

pageData.title: Step 6:
pageData.text: Convert the answer in Step 5 to the appropriate units, such as grams, volume, or concentration.

pageData.title: Step 7:
pageData.text: Calculate after determining experimentally.

pageData.subTitle: When working stoichiometry problems, always do the following:
pageData.text:
1. Write the units on all numbers.
  2. Check that the units cancel properly.
  3. Give the answer in correct units.
  4. Avoid rounding numbers too much during the calculation, but round the final answer to the correct number of significant figures.

pageData.question: When calculating stoichiometry, what is the best practice when rounding numbers?

options.text: Avoid rounding numbers too much during the calculation, but round the final answer to the correct number of significant figures.
Round numbers at each step during the calculation, and always round the final answer to four significant figures.
Avoid rounding numbers when reporting your final answer.
Avoid rounding numbers too much during the calculations, but always round the final answer to two significant figures.
Round numbers at each step during the calculation, and round the final answer to the correct number of significant figures.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Avoid rounding numbers too much during the calculation, but round the final answer to the correct number of significant figures.

pageData.question: Which of the following is NOT a step used to determine the product yield from stoichiometric calculations?

options.text: Identify the oxidizing agent and the reducing agent.
Identify the limiting reactant.
Calculate the percent yield after determining actual yield experimentally.
Balance the chemical equation for the reaction.
Calculate the number of moles of product.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: After balancing the chemical equation of the reaction, calculate the number of moles of each reactant and identify if one of the reactants is limiting. Then based on the limiting reactant and the balanced chemical equation, calculate the number of moles of product produced. Finally, after determining actual yield experimentally, calculate the percent yield.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
To determine product yield from stoichiometric calculations, use the following six-step process.
Step 1: Write a balanced chemical equation for the reaction.
Step 2: Balance the electric charges in the chemical equations.
Step 3: Calculate the number of moles of each reactant.
Step 4: Determine if one of the reactants is a limiting reactant.
Step 5: Calculate the number of moles of product produced based on the number of moles of the limiting reactant and the balanced chemical equation.
Step 6: Convert the answer in Step 5 to the appropriate units, such as grams, volume, or concentration.
Step 7: Calculate percent yield after determining actual yield experimentally.When working stoichiometry problems, always do the following:
  1. Write the units on all numbers.
  2. Check that the units cancel properly.
  3. Give the answer in correct units.
  4. Avoid rounding numbers too much during the calculation, but round the final answer to the correct number of significant figures.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
To determine product yield from stoichiometric calculations, use the following six-step process.
Step 1: Write a balanced chemical equation for the reaction.
Step 2: Balance the electric charges in the chemical equations.
Step 3: Calculate the number of moles of each reactant.
Step 4: Determine if one of the reactants is a limiting reactant.
Step 5: Calculate the number of moles of product produced based on the number of moles of the limiting reactant and the balanced chemical equation.
Step 6: Convert the answer in Step 5 to the appropriate units, such as grams, volume, or concentration.
Step 7: Calculate percent yield after determining actual yield experimentally.When working stoichiometry problems, always do the following:
  1. Write the units on all numbers.
  2. Check that the units cancel properly.
  3. Give the answer in correct units.
  4. Avoid rounding numbers too much during the calculation, but round the final answer to the correct number of significant figures.

pageData.subTitle: Step 1: Balancing Chemical Equations
pageData.text: The first and most important step in <button class='glossary-text'>stoichiometry</button> is writing a correctly balanced chemical equation. The balanced chemical equation should also include the physical state of each species. This will dictate how to convert between the number of moles and measurement units. For example, if magnesium metal and hydrochloric acid react to produce magnesium chloride and hydrogen gas, the balanced chemical equation is:
Mg(s) + 2HCl(aq) ➝ MgCl<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>(aq) + H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>(g)
The balanced chemical equation provides two important pieces of information.

text: Mole ratio: The equation coefficients are used to determine the molar ratio. One mole Mg reacts with two moles of HCl to produce one mole of MgCl<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> and one mole H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>.
Physical state: Mg is a solid, H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> is a gas, and HCl and MgCl<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> are both aqueous solutions.

pageData.subTitle: Step 2: Balancing Electrical Charges
pageData.text: Many chemicals dissolve into ions in water. They fall apart in atoms or elements containing an electric charge. In a chemical reaction, the electric charge on both sides of the equation needs to be the same. As an example, we are going to use water, H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O, which has no electrical charge. The elements that make up water do contain an electrical charge when dissolved. Hydrogen, or H, has one electrical charge. This is indicated by H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup>, where the plus sign indicates the positive electrical charge. When there is no number in front of the electrical charge, it means that there is only 1. Thus, in this case, hydrogen has an electrical charge of 1 plus. Oxygen has two negative electrical charges, indicated by O<sup class=bodySupscript>2-</sup>. The minus sign indicates an electrical charge, and the 2 indicates two negative charges.

In order to balance the reaction of creating water, the net electrical charge needs to be zero. The negative and positive charges need to cancel each other out. An easy way to do this is to multiply the electrical charge of the positive molecule by the number of negative molecules reacting, and multiply the number of negative charges times the number of positive molecules available. In this case, 1 hydrogen times 2 negative charges gives us 2, which indicates how many hydrogen ions we need to cancel out the 2- charge of the oxygen.
We can do the same for the positive charge. The positive charge times 1 oxygen ion gives us 1. We only need one oxygen ion to cancel out the positive charge of the hydrogen.

This will give us 2H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup> + O<sup class=bodySupscript>2-</sup> ➝ H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O. On both sides of the equation the net electrical charge is zero. The equation is now balanced.

pageData.subTitle: Step 3: Calculate the Number of Moles of Reactants
pageData.text: Dimensional analysis is used in stoichiometric calculations to convert between units such as mL and L. When setting up a stoichiometric calculation, dimensional analysis ratios should be oriented so the same units cancel each other out.

There are several different methods to perform dimensional analysis. Some instructors teach a method that uses grids to keep track of units. To keep track of units in the method shown here, the number always goes with the top unit and the bottom unit has an implicit ‘1’ as the number. For example, 15 g/mol should be written as 15 g/1 mol.

When setting up a stoichiometric calculation, begin with the units provided in the problem and convert the value to moles. If the reactant or product is a solid, begin with mass and divide by the molar mass calculated from the periodic table. If the reactant or product is a solution, start with molarity and multiply the volume to calculate moles. If it is a gas, use the ideal gas law (PV = nRT, where P is pressure, V is volume, n is number of moles, R is the universal gas constant, and T is temperature) to calculate the number of moles. To simplify this, if the gas is at standard temperature and pressure (STP), then one mole of gas occupies 22.4 L.
If 1.03 g of the magnesium metal and 100 mL of 0.5 M hydrochloric acid are used in the reaction above, the number of moles of the reactants are calculated as follows:

pageData.subTitle: Mg(s)
pageData.text: moles Mg = mass Mg/molar mass Mg
moles Mg = 1.03 g/24.3 g / mol
moles Mg = 0.0424 moles

pageData.subTitle: HCI(aq)
pageData.text: molarity = moles/volume in Liters
moles = molarity × volume in Liters
moles HCl = 0.5 M × 100 mL × 1 L/1,000 mL
moles HCl = 0.05 moles

pageData.subTitle: Step 4: Determine the Limiting Reactant
pageData.text: There are several different methods for determining the <button class='glossary-text'>limiting reactant</button>. One method is to determine the number of moles of product produced from each reactant. The reactant that generates the smaller amount of product will be the limiting reactant because it will be consumed first. Use the mole ratio of the reactant to product based on the coefficients in the balanced chemical equation. For the above example from step 3.

pageData.subTitle: Moles MgCl<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> produced based on Mg
pageData.text: 0.0424 moles Mg × 1 mole MgCl2/1 mole Mg
= 0.0424 moles MgCl<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>

pageData.subTitle: Moles MgCl<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> produced based on HCl
pageData.text: 0.05 moles HCI × 1 mole MgCl2/2 moles HCI
= 0.025 moles MgCl<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>

HCl is the limiting reactant because 0.025 moles of MgCl<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> is less than 0.0424 moles of MgCl<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>, therefore the hydrochloric acid will be consumed first. The Mg is an <button class='glossary-text'>excess reactant</button> because it still exists when all the HCl has been consumed.

pageData.subTitle: Step 5: Calculate the Number of Moles of Product Produced
pageData.text: Use the <button class='glossary-text'>limiting reactant</button> to calculate the number of moles of each product. In most problems, the number of moles of one of the products will have already been calculated in Step 4. Remember to use the proper coefficients from the balanced chemical equation.

pageData.subTitle: Moles MgCl<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> produced based on HCl

pageData.text: 0.05 moles HCI × 1 mole MgCl2/2 moles HCI
= 0.025 moles MgCl<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>

pageData.subTitle: Moles H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> produced based on HCl

pageData.text: 0.05 moles HCI × 1 mole H2/2 moles HCI
= 0.025 moles H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>

pageData.subTitle: Step 6: Convert Moles of Product to the Final Units
pageData.text: This step is similar to Step 3, but in reverse. Depending on the physical state of the product, convert moles to grams (solid), molarity (aqueous solution), or volume (gas). Remember that the solution volume will not change and that the gas volume is still subject to the ideal gas law (PV = nRT). In the example above, since the gas is produced at STP the temperature, pressure, and universal gas constant are the same on both sides of the equation and cancel out. This means that the gas volume can be calculated using a simple ratio.

pageData.subTitle: Step 7: Calculate Percent YieldMgCl2(aq)
pageData.text: molarity = moles/volume in Liters
molarity MgCl2 = 0.025 moles MgCl2/0.1 L
molarity MgCl<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> = 0.25 M MgCl<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>

pageData.subTitle: H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>(g)
pageData.text: 22.4 Liters of gas/1 mole of gas = X Liters of H2/0.025 moles of H2
= 0.56 Liters of H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>

The last step in some <button class='glossary-text'>stoichiometry</button> problems is to determine the <button class='glossary-text'>percent yield</button> of the reaction. Either product can be used to determine the percent yield. In general, it is easier to measure the mass or volume for solids and gases, respectively, than the molarity of a solution when calculating the yield.
If 0.49 Liters of H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> gas is produced in the example, what is the percent yield?
of H2/ of H2 × 100% = percent yield
0.49 L of H2/0.56 L of H2 × 100% = 87.5%

The percent yield tells us how well the reaction worked in terms of forming the desired product. A percent yield below 100% is common. It could be due to the reaction not going to completion or that some product loss occurred when it was transferred from one container to another or filtered. Side reactions also lead to lower percent yields since they consume some of the reactants or products. It is also possible to have a percent yield greater than 100%. This could be due to weighing errors or an additional substance present with the product, making it weigh more. Incomplete drying may also inflate percent yield because moisture adds to the weight of a solid product.

In this investigation, aluminum metal and a solution of copper(II) sulfate react to produce copper metal and an aluminum sulfate solution. A small amount of sodium chloride is added to the reaction as a catalyst. The chloride ion removes a very thin layer of aluminum oxide from the aluminum foil surface, allowing the copper to react with pure aluminum metal. Because the chloride ion is a catalyst and not involved in the overall reaction, it is not included in the balanced chemical equation.

pageData.question: During a chemical reaction, 11.91 g of product is made. The maximum calculated yield is 12.0 g. What is the percent yield of this reaction?

options.text: Not enough information available

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text:
Percent yield = (Actual yield/Theoretical yield) × 100%
Precent yield = (11.91 g / 12.0 g) × 100%
Percent yield = 99.25% = 99.3%

pageData.question: During a chemical reaction, 40.7 g of product is made. The maximum calculated yield is 63.9 g. What is the percent yield of this reaction?

options.text: Not enough information available.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text:
Percent yield = (Actual yield/Theoretical yield) × 100%
Precent yield = (40.7 g / 63.9 g) × 100%
Percent yield = 63.69% = 63.7%

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Percentage yield = [Actual yield (the quantity you produced in your experiment) / Theoretical yield (the calculated amount that should have been produced)] × 100%

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Percentage yield = [Actual yield (the quantity you produced in your experiment) / Theoretical yield (the calculated amount that should have been produced)] × 100%

pageData.desc: This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. If using the oven dry method, you will start by pre-heating the oven. You will then conduct a singlereplacement reaction using copper sulfate and aluminum foil, with sodium chloride. You will then filter out and wash the copper metal precipitate from the reaction solution and dry it. Finally, you will calculate the theoretical yield of this reaction and compare it to the actual yield of the reaction to determine the percent yield.
pageData.altText: This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. If using the oven dry method, you will start by pre-heating the oven. You will then conduct a singlereplacement reaction using copper sulfate and aluminum foil, with sodium chloride. You will then filter out and wash the copper metal precipitate from the reaction solution and dry it. Finally, you will calculate the theoretical yield of this reaction and compare it to the actual yield of the reaction to determine the percent yield.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing this activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing this investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Place the following steps for determining product yield using stoichiometric calculations in the correct order.

options.answer: Convert mole number to appropriate units

assestmentData.question: Which of the following describes a limiting reactant?

options.text: The complete consumption of the reactant causes the reaction to stop.
The complete consumption of the reactant decreases the reaction rate.
The addition of this reactant causes the reaction to stop.
The removal of this reactant increases the reaction rate.
The addition of this reactant shifts the reaction toward the reactants.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following suggestions is LEAST helpful when performing stoichiometric calculations?

options.text: Omit physical states in the balanced chemical equation.
Write the units on all numbers.
Check that units are cancelling out properly.
Give the answer in correct units.
Avoid rounding during the calculation until the final answer.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the percent yield of a reaction?

options.text: how closely the actual yield compares to the theoretical maximum yield
how closely the actual reaction rate compares to the theoretical rate
the percentage of the reaction completed before the limiting reactant was consumed
the percentage of the product that is stable
how closely the actual products compare to the theoretical products

assestmentData.question: Nelson has calculated that the percent yield for the chemical reaction he performed is less than 100%. Which of the following scenarios is MOST likely to explain this percent yield?

options.text: Some product was lost during a container transfer.
An additional substance was mixed with the product.
The wet product was not allowed to dry out completely.
The product was a gas rather than a solid.
The reaction went to completion.

assestmentData.question: In this investigation, you will determine the percent yield of a chemical reaction involving aluminum metal, copper (II) sulfate solution, and sodium chloride (table salt). Which of the following is considered the catalyst of the chemical reaction in this investigation?

options.text: chloride ion
sulfate ion
aluminum metal
copper metal
aluminum oxide

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is a safety hazard associated with the copper (II) sulfate solution provided in your lab kit for this investigation?

options.text: It is a tissue irritant.
It is a corrosive material.
It is highly flammable.
It produces harmful fumes.
It will stain skin and clothing.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the process you will use to isolate the copper metal produced by the chemical reaction performed in this investigation?

options.text: The metal is rinsed with pure water and completely dried.
The liquid products are filtered out leaving the metal behind.
The liquid products are boiled away leaving the metal behind.
The product solution is mixed with table salt to precipitate out the metal.
The solid products are passed through a sieve to isolate large metal particles.

Read through the procedure.
Obtain all the materials.
Clean and sanitize the work area.
If using the oven dry method, turn the oven on and set the temperature to 225 °F.

In this activity, you will conduct a single-replacement reaction using copper sulfate and aluminum foil, with sodium chloride (table salt) as a catalyst. You will then filter out and wash the copper metal precipitate from the reaction solution and dry it to remove all traces of water. Finally, you will calculate the <button class='glossary-text'>theoretical yield</button> of this reaction and compare it to the <button class='glossary-text'>actual yield</button> of the reaction to determine the <button class='glossary-text'>percent yield</button>.

pages.pageTitle:
A
 Single Replacement Reaction Stoichiometry and Percent Yield (37 steps)
pages.title: Single Replacement Reaction Stoichiometry and Percent Yield

pageData.text: Use the 50-mL graduated cylinder, measure all the 1 M CuSO<sub class=bodySubscript>4</sub> in the bottle, and place it in the 250-mL beaker. Record the total volume in the data table.

The bottle of copper sulfate will contain approximately 100 mL of solution. Use the 50-mL graduated cylinder. Measure 50 mL of solution and add it to the beaker. Measure out another 50 mL of solution and add that to the beaker. If there is less than 50 mL, record the volume before pouring. If some solution remains, measure that and add it to the beaker. The goal is to measure and record the starting volume of 1 M CuSO<sub class=bodySubscript>4</sub>.
Add some of the NaCl to the CuSO<sub class=bodySubscript>4</sub> solution using a teaspoon.
The sodium chloride is a catalyst so the exact amount is not important. One salt packet from a fast food restaurant will be sufficient.
Stir the solution with the plastic spoon to dissolve the NaCl.
Cut a 4 × 12" piece of aluminum foil.
Weigh and record the aluminum foil mass in the data table.

For best results, use between 1.4 and 1.6 g of aluminum foil. If the aluminum mass is too high, tear a little off until it is within this range. If the mass is too low, add some more foil. The aluminum foil does not have to be one piece for this reaction. When weighing the aluminum foil, fold it up so it fits in/on the electronic balance pan.
Tear the aluminum foil into small pieces (approximately 1 × 1") and add them to the CuSO<sub class=bodySubscript>4</sub> – NaCl solution.
CAUTION: The solution will get hot, but not hot enough to harm the plastic beaker.
With a plastic spoon, stir to mix the aluminum foil in the solution.
Record all observations.
Let the reaction mixture sit for approximately 10 minutes. Stir occasionally with the plastic spoon to ensure all the aluminum reacts.
The aluminum foil will float on top of the surface. Keep stirring to expose the aluminum on the foil until no more remains. Do not proceed to the filtration step if any aluminum is left.
After all the aluminum has reacted, let the solution sit for another 5 minutes, allowing the copper to settle to the bottom of the beaker.
Prepare the filtration set-up.
1. Fold the filter paper in half and then in half again. Tear a small piece from the corner of the filter paper. See Figure 2 below.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Diagram and photo showing how to fold filter paper and place it into the funnel
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram and photo showing how to fold filter paper and place it into the funnel

pageData.text:
1. The folded filter paper has four curved edges, two interior and two exterior. Gently separate an exterior edge from the three remaining edges until it makes a cone. Place the filter paper cone into the funnel.
  2. Wet the filter paper with pure water and push the filter paper down into the funnel until it is flush with the walls.
  3. Place the filter funnel on top of the 50-mL graduated cylinder.

When no more aluminum foil is observed and the copper has settled to the bottom of the beaker, carefully <button class='glossary-text'>decant</button> the solution into a plastic cup. Use the spoon to keep all the solid copper in the beaker. Pour out as much of the solution as possible without losing any copper solid.
Add approximately 20 mL of pure water to the beaker containing the copper solids. Stir the copper suspension with the spoon and pour it in the filter funnel.
Transfer as much copper into the filter funnel as possible; use the spoon to help. See Figure 3.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Photo of copper precipitate being scooped with a spoon into funnel with filter paper
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Photo of copper precipitate being scooped with a spoon into funnel with filter paper

pageData.text: Add another 10 mL of water to the beaker, swirl, and pour the rest of the water and copper solids into the filter funnel. You may need to empty the graduated cylinder to be able to complete the rinsing.
It may take 10–15 minutes for the liquid to pass through the filter.

Use a plastic pipet and wash the copper solid with another 20 mL of pure water. Also add the water around the outside edges of the filter paper. This will wash away most of the remaining sulfate solution. Any remaining sulfate solution will crystallize during the drying step and add to the weight of the final product.
Wait another 10 minutes for the wash to pass through the filter. See Figure 4.

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Photo of funnel with filter paper holding all of the copper precipitate
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Photo of funnel with filter paper holding all of the copper precipitate

pageData.text: CAUTION: The filter funnel gravity filtration set-up placed on top of the graduated cylinder is very top-heavy and prone to tipping over. Hold on to the cylinder base or weigh it down with heavy waterproof items to prevent it from tipping over.
Carefully remove the filter paper from the filter funnel.
Unfold the filter paper and lay it flat on several layers of paper towels to assist in the drying of the copper metal. See Figure 5.

pageData.desc: Figure 5: Photo of filter paper with copper precipitate removed from funnel and layed flat
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Photo of filter paper with copper precipitate removed from funnel and layed flat

typeBefore.title: Drying the Product
typeBefore.text: The product must be thoroughly dried before the product is weighed. There are two recommended drying options. Using an oven or allowing it to air dry overnight. Do not use a microwave to dry the copper metal.

pageData.text: Leave the wet filter paper on the paper towels for 10–15 minutes to wick away some of the moisture.
Preheat the oven to about 225 °F. Do not exceed 250 °F
Place the filter paper on a sheet of foil. Place the foil on a cookie sheet or pie pan.

Spread the moist copper product out using the spoon. The greater the surface area exposed, the quicker the copper will dry. Be sure to remove any lingering copper from the spoon and onto the filter paper.
Heat the copper metal and filter paper for 25–30 minutes to remove all the water.
If the filter paper starts to char, remove it from the oven. The copper should break apart easily when it is thoroughly dry. See Figure 6.

pageData.desc: Figure 6: Photo of filter paper with copper precipitate after being dried in an oven
pageData.altText: Figure 6: Photo of filter paper with copper precipitate after being dried in an oven

pageData.text: Remove the copper metal and filter paper from the foil and allow it to cool a few minutes.
Tare a weigh boat on the electronic balance.
Transfer the copper metal from the filter paper to the weigh boat.
Weigh the copper metal and record the mass in the Data Table.
Keep the wet filter paper on the paper towels and place it in a well-ventilated but secure location for 24 hours.
Occasionally replace the paper towels to facilitate the drying process.
Spread the moist copper product out using the spoon. The greater the surface area exposed, the quicker the copper will dry.
When the copper metal breaks apart easily with the plastic spoon, it should be dry enough for weighing. This takes at least 24 hours, depending on the humidity and air flow around the sample.
Tare a weigh boat on the electronic balance.
Transfer the copper metal from the filter paper to the weigh boat.
Weigh the copper metal and record the mass in the Data Table.

text: Dispose of all used sulfate solutions and filtrates in a sink with the water running. Allow the faucet to run a few minutes to dilute the solutions.
Clean and dry the beaker, graduated cylinder, filter funnel, pipet, and spoon before returning them to the equipment kit.
Sanitize the workspace.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

pageData.title: Questions
text: Describe the appearance of the copper(II) sulfate solution and the aluminum foil before the reaction starts.
Describe your observations of the solution during the reaction.
Describe the appearance of the solution and any solids after the reaction.
Describe the appearance of the solid after it is dried.
Was all of the copper(II) sulfate reacted in this lab? Explain your answer both with observations and calculations.
Identify the excess and limiting reactants.
Identify TWO aqueous substances that were washed away from the final solid.
If the solids were not washed before drying, how would this change the copper metal yield?
If the copper is not completely dried, how would this change the yield of copper metal?
Explain why the percent yield was not 100%. What are some sources of error?

pageData.altText: Periodic Table of the Elements

pageData.content: Figure 1. Example of a limiting reactant
pageData.altText: Figure 1: An analogy of a chemical reaction. 6 bread buns and 2 slices of cheese are on the left side of the equation as reactants. The cheese is labeled the limiting reactant. On the right side of the equation are 2 cheese sandwiches, each comprised of 2 buns and 1 slice of cheese. These sandwiches are labeled the theoretical yield. Also produced by the equation are 2 buns, which are labeled as excess reagent.

This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. If using the oven dry method, you will start by pre-heating the oven. You will then conduct a singlereplacement reaction using copper sulfate and aluminum foil, with sodium chloride. You will then filter out and wash the copper metal precipitate from the reaction solution and dry it. Finally, you will calculate the theoretical yield of this reaction and compare it to the actual yield of the reaction to determine the percent yield.

data.title: Actual yield
data.content: The amount of product actually generated by conducting an experiment.

data.title: Decant
data.content: Pour the liquid portion from one container to another with out disturbing the solid portion

data.title: Excess reactant
data.content: The reactant that is left over after the limiting reactant has been exhausted; this reactant did not limit the amount of product generated.

data.title: Limiting reactant
data.content: The fully consumed reactant that limits the amount of product generated.

data.title: Percent yield
data.content: Calculated by dividing the actual yield by the theoretical yield and multiplying by one hundred.

data.title: Stoichiometry
data.content: Calculations that are used in chemistry to determine the amounts of substances that react and how much they produce in a chemical reaction.

data.title: Theoretical yield
data.content: The theoretical amount of product that is calculated to be generated by an experiment.
